row.Body:
Sehr viele Märchen beginnen auf Deutsch mit "Es war einmal", aber ich kenne auch ein Märchen, das anfängt mit "Zu der Zeit, als das Wünschen noch geholfen hat ...".

Gibt es noch andere Beginnformeln und wenn ja, kann man diese dem geographischen Ursprung der Märchen zuordnen?

Many German fairy tales open with "Es war einmal", but some start with "Zu der Zeit, als das Wünschen noch geholfen hat ...".

Are there any other common introductions? If so, is there a correlation between their use and the geographic origin of the story?
row.Title: Gibt es andere übliche Märchenbeginnformeln neben "es war einmal"?

row.Body: What are good online dictionaries for translation between German and English?
row.Title: What are good online dictionaries for translation between German and English?

row.Body:
Is there a good on-line resource - free or not free - to look up the etymology of German words?

Something like Duden's "Das Herkunftswörterbuch"?
row.Title: Is there a good on-line resource to look up the etymology of German words?

row.Body: Each language has its own ideas of how to punctuate, e.g. space before question marks in French. How is German punctuation different from English?
row.Title: What are the differences in punctuation between German and English?

row.Body:
One of the things that I really liked about German, as I was studying it in college, was the very orderly grammar, which actually helped me to understand my native English better.

As a non-native speaker, one of the hardest things for me to do is remember the correct noun genders. When I speak German, I am intelligible, but I'm sure it sounds to a native speaker much as English as a foreign language sounds to me.

Are there tips and tricks to learning genders? Are there patterns that I might not be aware of that will save me from brute force memorization?
row.Title: How can I better learn noun genders?
